column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Check an Internal Meat Temperature

#Text=A meat thermometer checks the internal temperature of cooked meat to ensure that the meat is thoroughly cooked and hot enough to kill any harmful bacteria that might be present , without overcooking the meat .
#Text=A meat thermometer is also used to check the temperature of casseroles containing meat , meat loaves and egg dishes .
#Text=How to check an internal meat temperature depends on the meat and how you 're cooking it .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Buying a Thermometer
#Text=Read the label to make sure you 're buying a meat thermometer and not a candy or oven thermometer .
#Text=If you think you may have difficulty operating a digital thermometer , buy one with a needle gauge .
#Text=However , digital thermometers do have a distinct advantage .
#Text=They provide a more precise temperature reading in a matter of seconds .
#Text=This will keep less heat from escaping your oven or outdoor grill while your are checking the meat 's temperature .
#Text=Buy an instant-read thermometer for meats such as ground beef patties , pork chops or grilled chicken .
#Text=An instant read thermometer is inserted into the meat at the end of cooking time to check the internal temperature .
#Text=Purchase a probe thermometer for meats such as whole birds , ham , beef or lamb roasts .
#Text=A probe is designed to be inserted in the meat before the meat is placed in the oven , and allows you to monitor the temperature and know when the meat has finished cooking .
#Text=Use a meat thermometer specially designed for microwave use if you cook meat in the microwave .
#Text=Inserting the Thermometer
#Text=Insert a probe thermometer into the thickest part of the meat , being careful not to touch the bone , which will be hotter than the meat around it .
#Text=Do n't allow the thermometer to rest on the roasting pan or dish .
#Text=When cooking whole birds , insert the thermometer into the thickest part of the thigh with the readout or gauge toward the wing .
#Text=Be careful that the thermometer does n't touch the bone .
#Text=Test steaks , ground beef patties and other thinner cuts of meat by inserting an instant-read thermometer 1.3 cm ( 0.5 inches ) into the meat .
#Text=Be careful not insert the thermometer completely through the meat , and avoid touching the grill , pan or plate .
#Text=If you 're using a needle gauge , wait a few seconds for the needle to stop moving before reading the temperature .
#Text=Remove the thinnest cuts of meat from the stove-top or grill and test by inserting the thermometer from the side to prevent touching the thermometer to the pan or grill .
#Text=Temperatures
#Text=Grill or roast beef and lamb to different temperatures depending on the desired term .
#Text=These cuts of meat will have contaminating bacteria only on the outside , so it 's safe to leave the center less than thoroughly cooked .
#Text=Medium rare ( bright pink center ) : 63°C ( 145°F )
#Text=Medium ( light pink center ) : 71°C ( 160°F )
#Text=Well done ( no pink ) : 77°C ( 170°F )
#Text=Cook ground beef , pork , chicken or turkey to a temperature of 74°C ( 165°F ) .
#Text=Because the meat is ground , contaminating bacteria might be present throughout the meat .
#Text=It 's therefore never safe to serve ground meat that 's less than well done .
#Text=Roast whole birds or breasts to a temperature of 74°C ( 165°F ) .
#Text=You should also cook the stuffing to 74°C ( 165°F ) , since many stuffing recipes incorporate juices or other parts of the bird .
#Text=Roast , fry or grill pork to a temperature of at least 64°C ( 145°F ) .
#Text=It 's not safe to serve undercooked pork because the meat may contain parasites that cause trichinosis .
#Text=Heat a cooked ham until the internal temperature is 60°C ( 140°C ) .
#Text=An uncooked ham should be roasted until to 63°C ( 145°F ) .
#Text=Cook most fish to a temperature of 60°C ( 140°F ) .
#Text=Game fish such as tuna or marlin should only be cooked to an internal temperature of 52°C ( 125°F ) or it will dry out and become unpalatable .
#Text=Reheat all leftovers until they reach a temperature of 74°C ( 165°F )
#Text=Remove egg dishes and casseroles from the oven when the temperature reaches 71°C ( 160°F ) and casseroles when they reach 74°C ( 165°F ) .
#Text=Tips
#Text=When roasting meat , remove it from the oven when it reaches the desired temperature , but do n't remove the thermometer .
#Text=Leave it in place , and let the meat rest until the internal temperature stops rising .
#Text=The meat will continue to cook for up to 90 minutes , depending on its size .
#Text=It will be more tasty if allowed to rest .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Do n't rely on pop-up thermometers , which are not accurate , or on the color of the center of ground beef to determine the term .
#Text=When placing meat dishes on a buffet or otherwise allowing them to sit , use a thermometer to make sure the internal temperature stays above 60°C ( 140°F ) .
#Text=If it cools to below 60 degrees , contaminating bacteria may start to grow .
